sub_title: Associate Professor & Chair of Religious Studies at Leiden University
summary:
Corey L. Williams (PhD, Edinburgh) is a University Lecturer in Anthropology and Global Christianity at Leiden University. He is also the Chair of Religious Studies Programmes and Director of the Leiden University Centre for the Study of Religion (LUCSoR). 

Corey is a cultural anthropologist and African (Diaspora) Studies specialist with area expertise in (West) Africa and the United States. His research interests concern World Christianity, African (indigenous) religions, migration, anthropology of religion, interreligious encounters, and religion and public policy. His research has been awarded grants from the American Academy of Religion, Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Lilly Foundation, and Yale University.

Corey is also a Fellow at the African Studies Centre Leiden (ASCL) where he is part of a Collaborative Research Group (CRG) and a Faculty Fellow at the Ife Institute for Advanced Studies, Obafemi Awolowo University, Nigeria. Prior to joining Leiden University in 2015, he was a Visiting Professor of Religion at Pepperdine University (USA) and Lecturer in World Christianity and Religious Studies at Edinburgh University (UK).

Faculty website: http://universiteitleiden.nl/en/staffmembers/corey-williams

projects.title: Research Project: Islam in the Modern World
projects.description: I serve as the Regional Coordinator and Moderator for Sub-Saharan Africa on the Islam in the Modern World grant project. This four-year project brings together policy makers, diplomats, and regional experts for training and discussion on policy issues related to religion (especially Islam). The joint venture is directed by Maurits Berger (Leiden Islam Academie) and is in cooperation with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (The Hague, Netherlands), International Crisis Group (Brussels, Belgium), and the Centre for Professional Learning (Leiden University, Netherlands).

projects.title: Research Project: African Immigrant Religious Networks in California
projects.description: This project related to West African immigrants and religion in the U.S. To date I have conducted two short-term field visits to Los Angeles and formed an expert advisory committee: Afe Adogame (Princeton), Jacob Olupona (Harvard), and Gerrie ter Haar (Erasmus). Using a ‘Seed and Breed’ grant from the Centre for the Study of Islam and Society, I brought the committee together in December 2016 for a workshop to discuss my research. In January 2016, I submitted a grant proposal to the Netherlands Organisation for Scientific Research (NWO) titled, ‘African Immigrant Religious Networks: The Social and Political Engagement of African Initiated Churches in California’.

projects.title: Research Project: Religion in West Africa
projects.description: In my PhD research, I conducted 12 months of fieldwork in Nigeria documenting how and why the Yorùbá simultaneously belong to and/or identify with multiple religions. With two case studies, one of a masquerade festival and another of the ‘Chrislam’ movement, the project: (1) documented the continued role and influence of indigenous African religions; (2) contested how the existent literature narrowly focused on public interactions, politics, and violence, thus largely neglecting private interactions and surreptitious religiosity; and (3) problematized ‘essentialized religions’ and proposed that the Yorùbá concept of ‘accommodation’ is a standard feature of cultural interaction and is integral to not only understanding Yorùbá culture and society, but also West African religiosity in general. I am currently revising a monograph based on my PhD dissertation that is tentatively titled, Interreligious Encounter in a West Africa City: A Study of Multiple Religious Belonging and Identity Among the Yoruba.

profile_positions.description:
Courses Taught:
•	Religion and Culture: Currents in World Christianity

My primary duties were to design, lead, manage, and facilitate courses in the Department of Religion. This includes delivering lectures, moderating large and small group discussions, cultivating analytical skills, mentoring students, assisting students with course content and essay writing, recording attendance, leading students on fieldtrips to local religious sites, corresponding with students, marking and providing feedback (field reports, essays, and exams), and working with the Head of the Department and other departmental colleagues.

As a Teaching Assistant, my duties included marking and providing feedback for essays and exams, assisting with fieldtrips to local religious sites, and occasional lecturing.

As a Research Assistant, I worked with Dr. Dyron Daughrity performing quantitative demographic research for two books published by Peter Lang Academic: (1) The Changing World of Christianity: The Global History of a Borderless Religion; and (2) Church History: Five Approaches to a Global Discipline.
